v.v: Then Job answered and said,
“I truly know that this is so.
If he wants to argue with God,
God is wise in heart and mighty in strength;
he who removes the mountains without warning anyone
he who shakes the earth out of its place
It is the same God who tells the sun not to rise, and it does not,
who by himself stretches out the heavens
who makes the Bear, Orion, the Pleiades,
He does great and unsearchable things,
See, he goes by me, and I do not see him;
If he takes something away, who can stop him?
God will not withdraw his anger;
How much less could I answer him,
Even if I were righteous, I could not answer him;
Even if I called and he answered me,
For he breaks me with a tempest
He does not allow me to regain my breath;
If it is a matter of strength, behold, he is mighty!
Though I am in the right, my own mouth would condemn me;
I am blameless, but I do not care any more about myself;
It makes no difference, which is why I say
When a whip suddenly kills,
The earth is given into the hand of wicked people;
My days are swifter than a running messenger;
They are as fast as papyrus reed boats,
If I said that I would forget about my complaints,
I would be afraid of all my sorrows
I will be condemned;
If I washed myself with snow water
God would plunge me in a ditch,
For God is not a man, as I am, that I could answer him,
There is no judge between us
There is no other judge who could take God’s rod off me,
Then would I speak up and not fear him.

v: But how can a person be in the right with God?
he cannot answer him once in a thousand times.
who has ever hardened himself against him and succeeded?—
when he overturns them in his anger—
and sets its supports trembling.
and who covers up the stars,
and tramples down the waves of the sea,
and the constellations of the south.
and wonderful things that cannot be counted.
he passes on also, but I do not perceive him.
Who can say to him, ‘What are you doing?’
the helpers of Rahab bow beneath him.
could I choose words to reason with him?
I could only plead for mercy with my judge.
I would not believe that he was listening to my voice.
and multiplies my wounds without cause.
but he fills me with bitterness.
If it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?
and though I am blameless, my words would prove me to be guilty.
I despise my own life.
that he destroys blameless people and wicked people together.
he mocks the despair of the innocent.
God covers the faces of its judges.
If it is not he who does it, then who is it?
my days flee away; they see no good anywhere.
and as fast as the eagle that swoops down on its victim.
that I would take off my sad face and be happy,
because I know that you will not consider me innocent.
why, then, should I try in vain?
and made my hands ever so clean,
and my own clothes would be disgusted with me.
that we could come together in court.
who might lay his hand upon us both.
who could keep his terror from frightening me.
But as things are now, I cannot do that.
